Award.AbstractNarration:
As a result of rapid growth in the field of molecular biology, recent technological advances enable measuring the expression of thousands of genes simultaneously. However, simply measuring the expressions of multiple individual genes is insufficient to understand complex biological systems. To relate gene expressions to physiological states and environmental factors, gene expression networks are utilized. These networks enable the identification of previously unknown macroproperties of biological systems that emerge from interactions of multiple genes. Revealing these emerging properties relies on the precision of network reconstruction from experimental data. The major limitation for network reconstruction is usually the number of samples available for the study. This project develops a mathematical foundation for a new method of biological network reconstruction that relies on fundamental principles that connect correlation and causality. Reconstructing gene networks will lead to greater understanding of complex biological systems.

This project develops a new and more precise method of biological network reconstruction based on measuring the Proportion of Unexpected Correlations (PUC). This research extends into the mathematical theory of correlation inequalities and its applications. By using probability theory and statistical mechanics, this project will improve the precision in identifying the proportion of false gene connections attributed to noisy data in gene networks. This project has four primary components: (i) PUC investigations of interactions between the microbiome and host transcriptome; (ii) experimental validation the mathematical approach using metagenomic data; (iii) the development of a Cytoscape plug-in for the PUC analysis of biological data; (iv) interdisciplinary student research training in Systems Biology and Mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project concentrates on analyzing network structures in biology and beyond. The principal outcome of this work is the development of the Proportion of Unexpected Correlations (PUC) method for singling out the erroneous edges in gene correlation networks. The PUC method enhances the analysis of gene expression data. The theoretical justification of the PUC method uses the techniques from statistics, probability, and statistical mechanics. Specifically, our research merges the methods from statistical mechanics (such as Holley and Fortuin-Kasteleyn-Ginibre (FKG) inequalities) with the gene expression data in biology. Following our initial publications on the topic, the PUC method quickly gained some notoriety in the field.


One other principle outcome is the development of a novel technique for reconstructing (normalizing) gene correlation matrices. Our preliminary findings suggest that our innovative normalization technique outperforms the classical normalization methods such as Quantile, Rank, and Loess normalizations. Additionally, we examined (theoretically and using simulations) the impact of Quantile normalization on t-test in statistics of gene data.


As a spin-off from this project, we developed novel techniques in the overlap of statistical mechanics and probability theory. We gave a synopsis of these contributions in a book published by Springer. Also, as another spin-off from this project, we developed the theory of self-similar tree networks that we are summarizing in a survey paper (200 pages). Additionally, we have made contributions to the theory of associated random variables and FKG inequalities.
This project enabled us to train a Ph.D. student, providing the student with a unique cross-disciplinary skillset combined from the elements in four distinct fields: statistics, probability, statistical mechanics, and biology. 


The project results are disseminated in numerous invited presentations and publications including one book (Springer), seven published journal papers, two submitted journal papers, six journal papers in preparation, and one survey manuscript (200 pages, in preparation).
